An absurd game full of randomness – most of the time you can’t even do anything, just sit back and watch the game play you. You’re on a spaceship and suddenly your crewmates are out to kill you? But why? There’s a swarm of aliens hunting you down, and instead of fighting them, you’re supposed to kill your fellow crew members? Is this a joke?

Now imagine this: you’ve spent half the game gathering resources to craft a flamethrower. You finally face an alien – mind you, it’s twice your size – and… miss? Seriously? You miss with a flamethrower in a 3-meter room. Even if you manage to hit, it deals one point of damage, and the alien has 4 health. In this game, your best option when facing a monster is to just run away. That’s ridiculous.

To sum it up, half the characters in this game are useless and unplayable. For some unknown reason, your crew wants to kill you even though there’s a literal alien queen loose on the ship. Fighting the monsters is pointless because they’re way stronger than you. You’re heavily dependent on the cards in your hand – and honestly, most of them are pretty useless too.

Makes you wonder if anyone even tested this game.

5 new players took us about 3 hours to get halfway done and then we called it. One player survived on an escape pod, 2 players had died mid game, and 2 died at the end.

Note that you will probably die, although if you're going in to it for an experience you may like it. If you're trying to min/max, it is not going to be that good.

Things I'm fine with: moving around the ship, facing the bad guys, trying to get your objective done, etc.

What I didn't like/would house rule:
- the rules are just okay at best. They needed to be laid out better, with a glossary and some cross posting. E.g. one card let someone make another player retreat to a different room. Is that considered moving where they would have to make a noise check? There are a lot of these edge cases that could have been eliminated by rewording the rules, or using bolded keywords.
- Random alien hit points was so annoying. The mechanic killed an Adult on a 2 health, but others needed 5 or 6. Just make a hit point chart already. You don't need fluctuating hit points.
- It makes no sense that you have no idea where any rooms are on the ship, especially the ones that are adjacent to the hibernation pods. Those should start the game flipped over.
- You don't know where any rooms are, yet know how to get to the bridge or engine rooms.
- Trading should be free
- No way to remove noise. It just sits there until you have an encounter. If no one has been in the room for a few turns, that noise should have quieted down. I've read discussions of this that come to opposite conclusions. 1. It's the aliens hearing things in the room, and the noise markers are actually where they think people may be. OR 2. It's where you think you heard aliens coming from. Yet in both cases, after time, those markers should disappear. Both you and the aliens are not going to remember that 'oh yeah, 2 hours ago I heard some faint sound coming from this air shaft.'.

- There are too many extra rules that should have been eliminated or streamlined. This game screams for not enough taken out:
-- Crafting should be gone. It is so situational such that you could have just made those crafted items be regular items that you search for
-- The 2 different ways to get rid of Contamination cards depending on whether you were infected or not should just be a single method. Oh, you went to the Surgery room, scanned your cards but none are infected. Nope, you have to keep them all and go somewhere else to remove them. Why can't I just rest on the surgical bed?
-- Search should be a basic action rather than a card
-- Improving the bag needed to be different. Rather than a whole flow chart it should have simply been, you add the next higher alien type to the bag.
-- There is no reason you should have to get rid of one of your objective cards. Once I had chosen, a turn later, another player hopped in an escape pod and left. Well, my objective couldn't be done.
-- Why are items eliminated from the game when dropped but objects are not?

Player action : discard 1 card to move to an unexplored room.
Game response:
1.  Flip over randomly placed room tile.
2. Flip over randomly placed exploration token with a random effect and random number of items.
3. Roll the noise die (random result).
4. If the noise token would be placed in a corridor with another token resolve an encounter.
5. Draw a random intruder token from the bag.
6. Check the (usually) random number on the back.
7. If you get surprised draw a random intruder attack.
8. Check if the intruder type is able to use the attack.
9. If the intruder attacks, check if you get a heavy wound, if you do, draw a random heavy wound cards, and usually a random contamination card.
10. If you aren't dead you may do your second action/pass or the next player may act.

Nemesis (and it's various interations) is a bloated, miserable mess of KS funded board game spaghetti.

Players are crew on a ship playing the Alien movie franchise. You have your own secret agendas you must complete, then get you ass off the ship to safety.

On paper it sounds great- the game looks like the movie Alien, the artwork is like what you'd get if you asked an AI art app to create a load of Cyberpunk 2039 themed Dead Space art, and it looks great. The character portraits have loads of character, especially the ones from later expansions.

The rules also have loads of good sounding stuff. The aliens come in Chest Burster through Alien Queen sizes, the ship is random and has many rooms with different functions for the ship. Each character has unique action cards that only they can do. The secret agendas make you feel like the company mole, sabotaging the ship, altering the ships course, trying to get people killed. There's an infection system that clogs your action hands, and if you escape you have to scan them all with a special colour filter, and if you are actually infected you die anyway, so you gotta go get cleared of possible contamination. There's power systems, fire protocol, a crafting system.. The list goes on.

And that's the real issue. Nemesis is a hulking pile of Alien themed stuff poured into several boxes until they are all overflowing. The result is an overwhelming list of rules, systems and exceptions to teach and track. Every game half the rules need to be reexplained, usually a quarter of them three times, sometimes more even then that, because Nemesis is overly complex rules salad that even experienced players constantly struggle to keep hold of.

I get why it's so popular. The various expansions and all the rules mean you have a sandbox of Alien/sci-fi horror stuff that can do a good job of capturing the oppressive and miserable tone of the source material quite well. Does it make a good game system? Eh..

Its a 'losing by degrees' style game. The strongest you will ever be is in the first couple of turns whilst there's no enemies. As soon as event cards start queueing the game spirals into a mechanical beat down as you find yourself trapped in a room on fire, aliens in every room around you, your room's ability is malfunctioning, your weapons do next to nothing, you are bleeding out, contamination clogs your hand so you can't move, you are in darkness and you somehow aren't dead, but you can't do anything, so you just throw yourself mindlessly against the bad things, because it's either do and struggle on or die and finally get to go home and leave the other suckers to keep playing. None of these options are fun, just hopeless and demoralising.

Some people will say that's a successful simulation of the genre. I say that when nothing feels fun it's a bag of dicks. Nemesis is an unfun, miserable bag of dicks.

At least if it's cooperative I can lament with my friends about our trials and tribulations.. Oh right, it's a semi-coop, so nobody is helping each other either as they are all worried about being in each other's crosshairs.

The expansions add various flavours of sci-fi horror, including Dead Space Carnophages, Pitch Black darkness monsters, Lovecraftian ethereal monsters, as well as new boards, etc.

Interestingly I like Arkham Horror 2nd which can also be a random emotional beatdown at times, so what's the difference here? Maybe it's that sometimes you are actually winning in AH.. In Nemesis you are always on the back foot, with many mechanics that should be helpful often being irrelevant or ineffective, whilst the enemy systems are overwhelming and difficult to keep on top of.

All in all it's not the definitive Alien game for me. Think that's probably still Space Hulk for all it's simplicity.

So Nemesis long. The teach is far from trivial. We had someone experienced teach the game. I would personally hate to do it, but they loved doing it and did a pretty good job only getting one minor rule wrong. While the game has a lot of (read: too many) rules, the flow is surprisingly easy. It uses a nice card mechanism that holds the whole thing together: use cards for their powers (generally speaking) or discard them for basic actions. Even on a learning game, it was easy to piece it together bit by bit because many things don't take effect until later in the game. Lots of rules yet approachable and drip-feeding.

Players draft secret objectives which force players to make unusual decisions. This helps fuel the narrative of the game. Often times you will need several things to happen to win, so it's about trying to string together the pieces to enable them to happen. The semi-cooperative part works very well in my opinion. Players need to work together to have shots at their objectives which means they need to be open and honest about what they need. That, of course, allows for backstabbing and lies to come into play. There is a lot to talk about with the theme and how it comes into play. Some of my favorite moments: one player making a mad dash and escaping off the ship in the mid-game; three players deciding to cooperate and stick together only to have one break off from the pack to pursue their own objective (everyone died because of that), one player starting a grudge and locking someone in with the queen - another player breaking down the door - then the queen patrolling onto the begrudged player's square and killing him.

One of the coolest mechanics is getting contaminated - usually by being scratched by an alien. You don't know if you are infected or not, and if you are infected at the end of the game, then you automatically lose. You need to analyze the contamination to see or not, and you do so by sliding the card into a decoder which tells you. If you are infected, then you need to figure out a way to heal yourself before the end of the game - generally on top of whatever you were already trying to do. Swingy but very thematic and well-executed.

The only thing I didn't like about the game was how long it was once everyone was split up. I don't care what is happening on your turn if you are so far away from me, and with 5-10 minute turns sometimes - that adds up. Nemesis is overly long, but I enjoyed most of it and thought the story at the end of it all was worth it. This is Ameritrash done very well. Chromey but without the finicky rules.

Okay - one more thing I don't like. The game has too many symbols and has some graphical design issues that could have been streamlined. They are minor, but things like using glass beads vs. using counters.

EDIT: Follow-up play was nowhere near as cinematic but just as long. I think one issue with the game is how difficult the goals are and how little control you have in achieving them. The group needs to become convinced to play this as a cooperative game for the good guys to win. Down a notch.

I'll start by saying I was very excited to play this game and enjoyed playing it. However, it was far from perfect and contained a lot of annoyances- enough that it pushed my ranking down to "Not so good - but could play again" territory. This is #17 on boardgamegeek as I'm writing this, and I have to say... I'm not sure it's the 17th best game I've played in the last month. I think this is a game that has mostly thrived on hype, theme and the overall experience. It does provide a memorable experience.

The first and major issue to touch on is the luck/randomness factor. It's substantially too long for the amount of randomness it contains. The luck in this game is not only pervasive, but it is of the annoying, unmitigated kind. Things might arbitrarily just line up for you through no good choices of your own. Get the right cards in your hand at the right time? Great- you are going to do better than the person who can't time the appearance of cards with what they need to do..

The balance is another issue which has become apparent after a couple plays. The objectives can randomly be easy or very difficult based on timing of rooms, spacing and random effects. Your objective is to destroy the nest? It's revealed early and starts on fire? Congrats- the game decided your objective is easy. You need to analyze an egg or carcass and one falls into your lap right next to the laboratory? Yeah... These objective difficulties are wildly dependent on luck.

The infection cards and ways of dealing with them are near the top of my list of annoyances. Several things that scan those cards and/or remove them require you to have them in your hand. Line yourself up and then watch as you don't draw what you need, while someone else handles them with ease... Annoying.

Another issue- I dislike that some actions (like searching) aren't a basic action. There is no thematic reason for you to have to wait for a specific card to do that. It's just gamey crap to fill up a deck. I think I would have liked this game a LOT more if that deck of cards was just a worker placement style player mat. Have each action require a certain amount of time and give each player 5 time tokens. Let the players decide how to approach each turn instead of the deck. Maybe some actions take an extra turn to clear out (or something similar) to limit some of the more powerful actions- but give those choices and open that decision space to the players. Many of my annoyances with this game are directly tied to the action deck.

Also- a small irritation: sound lasting on the board indefinitely? Sound should be thematic, but this game treats it as a static, permanent landmine waiting for someone to step on it. Sound should go away over time, especially if there is no one near it.

All that and I haven't even touched on player elimination. Did I mention my first game I sat out for 1.5 hours waiting for the game to finish? (and that was a three player game I won after 2 hours). Ugh.

Nemesis is a multiplayer survival game unofficially adapting the Alien movies by Awaken Realms.

Replaced by:
Nemesis: Lockdown (aka Nemesis v1.5) is still 90% the same game, but it fixes some of the mechanical gameplay issues of Nemesis (see Cons).

What makes it special?
* Theme: the unofficial Alien game
* Harsh, survival atmosphere
* Combat against Aliens with unknown health
* Semi-cooperative survival game: NPC against players and players against players with personal secret goals (similar to Dead of Winter). It is all about making sure that your character will survive.

Pros:
+ Theme: Alien the board game
+ Good artwork
+ Components: plenty of detailed, gorgeous looking minis
+ Modular board with random room set-up each game
+ Exploration: players have to explore the rooms of the ship
+ Fun combat due to variable Alien life (high uncertainty). Hits are based on dice (however, very little mitigation). Aliens are very strong, not easy to kill, and a real threat (especially because ammo is scarce).
+ Harsh, tense, survival atmosphere (low ammunition, risky movement, push-your-luck dice rolls)
+ Common goals (bring ship to earth intact) combined with conflicting secret goals
+ Strategic semi-coop gameplay: stall your actions and wait for your teammate to trigger an encounter, help other players(???), selfish secret goals, self-destruction of the ship, keeping the ship intact: malfunctions and fire. Staying together has some advantages, however, secret goals give players reason to separate. The game feels more like an egoistic multiplayer solo game than a cooperative game.
+ Secret objectives similar to Dead of Winter like "player number 5 must die" but you are not allowed to directly attack other players, so you have to sabotage or hurt them somehow indirectly (which is not easy to accomplish). Usually the Aliens will do the job for you anyway (without your help).
+ Hard difficulty (the game can swing quickly into a downward spiral)
+ Equipment is quite useful
+ The high randomness sometimes lead to fun results and group experiences
+ Scales quite well with most player counts
+ Eliminated player may take over the role of the aliens that makes the game even harder for the other players and will end the game faster. This fact may encourage for more cooperation between players to prevent someone from dying.

Neutrals:
# Language dependent: text on cards
# Solo mode available
# Quite high luck factor, especially for combat encounters. Little opportunities for luck mitigation.
# Luck of the draw (items, hand cards)
# Due to randomness and erratic Alien behavior, some games feel rather lackluster (not enough is happening)
# Aliens act very samey except for the face hugger (expansions adds new Alien types)
# Escaping in an Escape Pod seems to be more safe and efficient than in stasis because of the uncertainty where the ship is headed
# Potential player elimination: a player may either die or leave the ship very early. However, this player takes over the control of the Aliens which makes the game extremely hard for the remaining surviving players and will definitely end the game soon for everyone.
# Plenty of tokens and cards to organize

Cons:
- Rules require constant referencing and re-checking. The rules are not elegant and could be much more streamlined without losing anything gameplay-wise or atmosphere-wise (say "hello", Alien bag!).
- Basic characters do not play very differently (nearly same deck of cards).
- Using escape pods is way better than cryo stasis to win the game. Cryo stasis is a hail mary due to the very little chance of survival (repaired engines + correct course + ship does not self-destruct + no infection).
- Some turns are not exciting: Do healing. Next player. Do repairing. Next player. Walk to room to re-check what another player has done. Next player. Most of the time the game feels like pick-up-and-delivery and it takes several turns to get somewhere or get anything done. Technically, Nemesis is a race game, where you have to play most efficiently against the time. And you also need some, no, a lot of luck.
- Mechanically, the game is somehow contradictory... Sometimes it is better to do just nothing on your turn. It is often very risky to move because you likely trigger an Alien because the Noise markers never disappear otherwise. Instead, you may wait for your team mates, to do the dirty work, but this may not happen. :-)
You have to pass for the whole round, if you do nothing on your turn. This way, the game tries to force you to do something instead of stalling. Encounters are less dangerous when you end your turn early and still hold many cards in your hand (thus, do as less as possible and only what is absolutely necessary). So mechanically, it is better to do nearly nothing than to do something.
- If you become infected you loses so many actions and rounds in summary, just to get rid of the Alien: you have to find and move to the operation room, heal yourself, pass for the rest of the round and..., oh, the game is already over?
- Very few opportunities to mediate dice rolls. Luck-based events often cause harsh, brutal gameplay. Death may be sudden if you are already injured. There is tension to this: if you are weak, you tend to get bashed even more (downward spiral).
- Not much cooperation or interaction between players in semi-coop mode. The game is based on efficient play. Often it takes too much time, to cooperate or interact with someone else directly.
- The traitor mechanic is used as a key mechanic to promote the game, but I think it is often misunderstood. Nemesis is about exploring and surviving in the first place. Yes, it has a semi-cooperative mode, but you should not expect a Battlestar Galactica or Dead of Winter. The semi-cooperative mode is like a multiplayer survival solo game where each player first tries to make sure his/her character will survive and other players do the same while everyone is changing the state of the ship. E.g., resources are scarce and you may have to walk from one side of the ship to the other just to find maybe some left ammo if nobody else loots it before you do.
- Some secret goals are too easy to guess after you know which goals exist in the game. Some goals are also easier to accomplish than others.
- Rotatable rooms indicate the number of searchable resources - a neat idea but it feels clunky and my alignment OCD does not like it when texts are differently rotated on the main board.
- I don't like square rulebooks/player's aids. They are unhandy!
(-) Variability is rather low due to low variety of the items and player cards. However, the random map and secret goals as well as the random behavior of the aliens ensure a different game each play (maybe expansions and KS exclusives improves this).

Thoughts:
I really like the setting and the general idea of the game. The biggest plus is the game's atmosphere of uncertainty and harsh survival. However, Nemesis lacks some elegance rules-wise and might feel repetitive over time. You usually have very limited actions each round.
Although I am a fan of semi-cooperative games, I think I might like it more cooperatively, because Nemesis is already very hard and some secret goals make it even harder. I do not think Nemesis should be seen as a traitor game in the first place. It is all about exploring and surviving. The traitor mechanic is neat, but not as important as promoted. Sabotaging the ship's direction or engines sounds like fun but it consumes a lot of additional time for the other players to move through the ship and check what a player has done. Yes, it invites for trusting and lying which is cool, but gameplay-wise, I think it is too easy for the traitor and too hard for the other players to check and stop that player (besides your main goal which is surviving the game at all).
Despite all the negative points, I still like Nemesis. I am mostly disappointed about the mechanical implementation of the game. The harsh survival atmosphere is great what makes the game stand out. Rewards are very rare in this game. The miniatures look great and Alien-like even without the official license. I am not inclined to play Nemesis every week but every now and then.

Similar games:
* Lifeform (Alien theme, 1 vs many, no player elimination, similar card play, quicker playing time, no miniatures)
* Dead of Winter (semi-coop survival game with more variation and player interaction)
* Stationfall

Nemesis – The unofficial Alien board game in everything but name — and atmosphere to spare. You wake from cryosleep aboard a silent ship, systems failing, engines sputtering… and something else is moving in the dark. Together, you and your crewmates must repair the ship, check the course, and try to survive — all while quietly pursuing your own secret objectives. Cooperation is essential… until it isn’t. Maybe you “accidentally” seal a door with a Xenomorph and a teammate inside. Oops. The rules can be a bit fiddly and the playtime hefty, but no other game captures cinematic tension quite like this. Every session feels like a full-blown sci-fi thriller — equal parts terror, betrayal, and glorious disaster.

BUT, if the metrics by which one assesses a boardgame is the amount of pleasure, fun and emotions they provide, then this is an astounding game. Once you learn the algorithms, the magic of the perfectly tuned probabilities quicks in. The game's randomness is of the best kind, generating endless memorable twists both in your favor and against you. The strong theme and immersion translates those twists into an unforgettable emotional roller coster.
